Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research in Computational Neuroscience (CRCNS) 2010 Principal Investigator's Meeting in Baltimore

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration: The PIs and Co-PIs of grants supported through the NSF-NIH Collaborative Research in Computational Neuroscience (CRCNS) program meet annually. This will be the sixth meeting of CRCNS investigators. The meeting brings together a broad spectrum of computational neuroscience researchers supported by the program, and includes poster presentations, talks and plenary lectures. The meeting is scheduled for June 6-8, 2010 and will be held at Johns Hopkins University.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Computational Neuroscience is an interdisciplinary science that has been advancing rapidly in recent years. Collaborative Research in Computational Neuroscience (CRCNS) program has been a major source of federal funding that fosters the interaction and collaboration between experimental and computational neuroscientists. This grant provided support to the 2010 Collaborative Research in Computational Neuroscience (CRCNS) Principal Investigator's (PI) Meeting, which took place on the Homewood campus at Johns Hopkins University, Baltimore, Maryland, June 6-8, 2010. The principal investigators and co-investigators of CRCNS grants were required to budget travel funds in their proposals to attend an annual meeting per the CRCNS proposal submission guidelines.  The meeting enabled the principal investigators and co-investigators to report on the progress of their projects, to discuss current research issues, opportunities, and practical concerns, and to facilitate continued collaborative funding and coordination. The presentations at the meeting included both short talks and poster sessions, in addition to longer, invited talks. The attendees of the meeting included current principal investigators and co-investigators of CRCNS grants, students and postdoctoral researchers involved in CRCNS funded projects, officers from the federal agencies which supported the CRCNS program, and people from the local Johns Hopkins scientific community. The program of the meeting is available to the public online.

 


Last Modified: 08/31/2011
Modified by: Kechen Zhang
